text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with bourbon-glazed carrots that's
right in my opinion this is the greatest
special occasion carrot side dish of all
time and while that assertion may be
debatable when no one can deny is how
incredibly glossy these are and as we've
gone over before people love shiny food
so with the Easter holiday coming up let
me show you how to make this incredibly
delicious and super simple side dish so
we're going to start by prepping two
pounds of carrots and by the way I don't
buy the bags of carrots I always buy
loose carrots so I can pick out ones
that are all the same thickness it just
makes life easier when you're cutting
them and then of course we got to peel
them and here is a great professional
prep cook tip peel in both directions
that's right one of these straight
peelers works both ways so I just slowly
turn the carrot while peeling in both
directions and if my mathematical
calculations are correct you will finish
in half the time so when it comes to
carrots you definitely want to go both
ways and then once they're peeled we're
going to go ahead and cut those up so
we're going to go ahead and trim off the
tip and the top and one thing I like to
do I like to put a towel around the edge
of the board because sliced carrots our
famous for trying to escape the cutting
board so this way when they roll they're
going to hit the towel and then as we
start cutting we're going to pay
attention to the shape of the carrots so
where the carrots the most tapered we
will cut a little thicker piece a little
wider cuts and then as we get closer to
the thicker end we will make our cuts a
little less wide and while these pieces
aren't exactly the same shape they will
cook in relatively the same amount of
time so on the tapered end of the carrot
I'll start out with thicker slices
and then as I move up towards the bigger
end I'll make the cuts a little less
thick
so to summarize where the carrots
thinner cut them thicker and where the
carrots thicker cut them thinner and of
course if you're cool you'll line two or
three up to make the cutting go a little
quicker all right and there we go our
carrots have been peeled and cut and we
are ready to get our glaze on so we're
going to head over to the stove we're
have a large heavy skillet on
medium-high heat we're going to melt a
whole stick of butter and whenever a
recipe starts with a whole stick of
butter I will add the disclaimer that
this is the kind of side dish you only
eat once or twice a year so relax it's
supposed to be over-the-top decadent
hence the special occasion designation
so please save your cards and letters
for someone that they will have an
effect on alright so once the butter is
melted and foams up we're going to add
our carrots if you're using a similarly
sized pan you should be able to get them
in one layer or close to it we're going
to go ahead and add some salt and then
we're basically going to cook these
carrots for about five or six minutes in
that butter until a couple things happen
now similar to when we do mushrooms and
other vegetables that salt is going to
draw out some water in the carrots and
they're going to look like they're
simmering in their own juices which they
are but a couple minutes later that's
going to evaporate and they will start
sauteing in that butter and you'll see
they'll start to slightly Brown around
the edges it'll be a little bit of
caramelization happening and we're not
cooking them all the way through here by
the way these are going to simmer in the
glaze so we're only going to do this for
about five or six minutes like I said
what you're looking for is that excess
liquid to evaporates and for the edges
to just start to caramelize a little and
at that point we're going to turn the
heat down to medium-low and we're going
to introduce our bourbon and we're going
to carefully pour in an entire 1/2 cup
now be careful this really shouldn't
flare up but it could so be careful when
you add it in case you get some flames
you want to lose your eyebrows so we're
going to stir in that bourbon and we're
going to cook that on medium low for
about two or three minutes until most of
that bourbon evaporates and it will look
like you're back to just melted butter
and then when that happens you are ready
for the last major piece of the puzzle
the brown sugar so we're going to pour
in some brown sugar I'm going to take my
spoon Yola I'm going to mix that in and
that's going to form the most amazing
bourbon syrup that you're ever going to
come across so give it a good stir and
then all we're going to do is cook these
stirring until they're is done as you
want so give them a mix every minute or
two and I'm going to guesstimate in
about five minutes
you will have perfectly cooked carrots
all right we don't want them soft and
mushy there should be a little firmness
in the center of course you're going to
test them with a fork and at this point
mine we're just about there
95% there and at that point I like to
turn up my heat maybe up to medium
possibly medium-high and just give that
glaze a final reduction of course you
got to play it by ear if your glaze is
getting too thick and the carrots aren't
cooked yet add a little splash of water
all right if your carrots seem like
they're almost tender and you
too much liquid turn the heat up you
must adjust okay and then once you're
happy with your glaze and the doneness
of your carrots I like to finish with a
little bit of cayenne a little bit of
freshly ground black pepper and that is
just one incredibly gorgeous vegetable
side dish we're going to spoon those up
on our serving platter up to you but I'm
going to garnish with a few time leaves
I just really think that works well here
totally optional though but it looks and
smells nice and that is ready to enjoy
with this special occasion entree of
your choice so whether it's a Christmas
or Easter ham or a Thanksgiving turkey
this is just a perfect side dish and it
really does taste as amazing as it looks
and I know what some of your thinking is
that just like eating candy well no it's
not
most candies have way more nutritional
value than this but that's not the point
like I said at the beginning this is
something you eat once or twice a year
and you do it guilt-free with no
apologies and that's just the kind of
dish this is so I really hope you give
this a try head over to food wishes comm
for all the ingredient amounts and more
info as usual and as always enjoy
